thread.title: State golf: Top Dawgs ready to let 'er rip
thread.title_full: State golf: Top Dawgs ready to let 'er rip

title: State golf: Top Dawgs ready to let 'er rip
text:
State golf: Top Dawgs ready to let 'er rip Jon Spencer , Reporter 8:34 p.m. EDT October 12, 2015 Buy Photo Brock Kehres and Alexis Jones, the 2014 state runner-up, are state qualifiers for Shelby along with teammate Claire Korbas (not pictured). (Photo: Mitchell Pe Masilun/News Journal) Buy Photo 9 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
SHELBY — This isn't her first rodeo, so to speak, so Alexis Jones is in position to offer this sage advice to greenhorns Claire Korbas and Brock Kehres as the three prepare to represent Shelby in this weekend's Division II state golf tournaments: 
Trust in your game. 
"Be confident in yourself," Jones, a junior three-time qualifier and 2014 medalist runner-up, offered to the Whippets' two first-time participants. "If you put in the work beforehand, state is just a big stage to show what you can do." 
Jones practically lives on the Shelby Country Club course, mentored by her dad, Ken. The other two have work ethics beyond reproach as well. 
Korbas was late to practice Monday and missed a photo shoot with the News Journal, but she had an excellent excuse. She was working on a school honors project. Korbas, a sophomore, hopes to own a college associates degree by the time she finishes high school. Buy Photo 
Claire Korbas (Photo: News Journal) 
"She's a genius," Jones said. "I'm not sure abnormal is the right word, but she came out to the course in her eighth grade year and I said, 'Dad, there's a girl out here.' And she was there the next day and the next day ... I don't know if it was inborn, but she developed a different work ethic than a normal freshman. She'd ask my dad for help and put in the hours after practice." 
Anybody that knows Jones would say she was describing her own approach to golf. At this point Shelby girls coach Brad Ruminski — the pro at Shelby C.C. — knows to leave well enough alone with both of his players. 
"I'm letting them do their thing," Ruminski said. "Any tweaking will be on a need-be basis. I'm letting them get their practice in and they're both focusing on their short game, which is key for (long-hitter) Alexis. Claire's got to keep her drives going. She's driving it exceptionally well the last couple of times out, and she needs to take care of pitching and putting as well." 
Jones and Korbas will be playing on Ohio State's Gray Course while Kehres will tee off at the North Star Resort, about 15 minutes north of Columbus. Kehres already got a taste of pressure last week when he won a three-hole playoff for district medalist runner-up honors after shooting a 76 in regulation. Buy Photo 
Brock Kehres (Photo: Mitchell Pe Masilun/News Journal) 
"I was excited about (the playoff)," he said. "I played in one this summer and won it, but another time they just let a scorecard playoff decide it. At districts we were asked how we wanted to do it. The manager said he never had two guys tie for second, and he didn't know the procedure, so we decided to keep playing. I'm glad because you've got to learn how to handle the pressure." 
Kehres has broken 80 in his last four rounds, firing a 74 for runner-up honors in the Northern Ohio League Tournament, 79 at the Edison Invitational, 79 under extremely tough conditions as sectional champ and then the 76 last week at Red Hawk Run in Findlay. 
"Toward the end of the season I had a match against Norwalk where I shot 37 or 38 and after that I kept going; my confidence started building up," said the Shelby junior, whose play over the last month has lowered his season average to 81. "I told myself to go in with no expectations this season, but my goal was to make it to state. Obviously, I'd like to win, but top 12 would be pretty good because that means you're All-Ohio. 
"The pressure's going to be there, but I've got to act like I don't feel it." 
Off the course, Jones and Korbas have different ways of preparing for state. Jones, a sectional and district champ, didn't look to see who else is in the field or what they shot at districts. Buy Photo 
Alexis Jones (Photo: Mitchell Pe Masilun/News Journal) 
"I don't even know when I tee-off Friday," she said before being informed it's 10:20 a.m. 
Korbas, on the other hand, not only knew when she was starting but did a background check on the other girls in her threesome. 
"It's hard to soak it all in," said Korbas, whose 80 at districts was third overall and second among individual qualifiers behind Jones' 75. "I noticed I'm teeing off with two seniors who have been to state before. The biggest thing is to be confident because I made it here. I worked to get here. It's great teeing off with seniors because they'll know what's up." 
Shelby sophomore Claire Korbas works on her putting. (Photo: Submitted) 
Jones definitely knows what's up. She came within a stroke of winning state last year, finishing one stroke behind 2011 state champ Haylee Harford of Leavittsburg LaBrae and two strokes ahead of 2013 state champ Makayla Dull of Kansas Lakota. They were both seniors. 
"She's like a mentor to me," Korbas said. "If I need anything, she can explain it. She's super-educated about golf and she's taught me a lot and told me a lot about the Gray course. I've researched it and looked at scorecards, but it's not the same as playing it." 
Kehres feels a big key to his stretch run has been buying what first-year coach and Shelby alum Justin Schroeder has been selling. Buy Photo 
Shelby state qualfieirs Brock Kehres and Alexis Jones see their reflection in a golf club. Not pictured is teammate Claire Korbas, also a qualifier. (Photo: Mitchell Pe Masilun/News Journal) 
"The mental aspect with him is so much different than my first two years," Kehres said. "He's always preaching not to let one bad hole ruin your round, always think about the positive and always pick out a good target. If you hit your target, regardless of the results, think positive because you hit it right where you wanted." 
Schroeder, who played for small college power Ohio Wesleyan, said the mental part of his own game was always strong, crediting his high school coach, Pat Lewis, and his college coaches. 
"Brock's score was better at district, but I think his round was better at sectionals because of the awful conditions," Schroeder said. "He focused on what he could control. You eliminate half the field that is complaining about the wind and weather. Brock did a good job of controlling his emotions." 
Jones doesn't remember leaving herself with anything but long putts once she reached the greens the second day of last year's state tournament. So she's placed extra emphasis on her pitching chipping. 
"The last three days I hit nothing but 40-yard shots so I'll be confident and execute; there's five par 3s on this course," she said. "I'm also referring back to my notes, where I missed last year, where I have to be deadly." 
A foul-weather fan because she feels it give her a mental edge over fair-weather competitors, Jones hopes Friday's weather forecast holds up. 
"It's suppose to rain, so I'm excited," she said, smiling. "Calm, but excited." 9 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://ohne.ws/1RDt9KN More Stories
